item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Tensions Escalate on Israel-Lebanon Border as Gaza Reels From Deadly Strikes
item.description: Growing attacks have forced thousands from their homes on both sides of the border between Lebanon and Israel, while Israeli forces continue to pummel the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning over people killed in strikes, at the morgue of the Nasser medical center in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Putin’s Drive to Rewrite History Snares a Retired Lithuanian Judge
item.description: A few years ago, Kornelija Maceviciene ruled against Soviet officers for a brutal crackdown on pro-independence protesters in her country in 1991. That has made her a target for a Russian court.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kornelija Maceviciene, 70, near the entrance of Vilnius District Court in Lithuania. “I really can’t figure out their logic,” she said of the Russian authorities. “The facts of the case are clear.”

item.title: Iraq Condemns U.S. After Drone Strike in Baghdad
item.description: The attack, acknowledged by the Pentagon, killed a senior militant leader of an Iran-allied group with ties to the Iraqi government’s security apparatus.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The coffin of a Harakat al-Nujaba member being carried in Baghdad after Thursday’s strike.

item.title: Killing of Hostages Leads Israelis to Question How Army Conducts Battle
item.description: Israel’s military said that soldiers who shot hostages, while they waved a white flag, violated its rules of engagement. Human rights activists say the rules are good, but enforcement is lax.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in December in northern Gaza.

item.title: Winter Storm Traps Hundreds of Motorists Overnight in Sweden
item.description: Truck drivers and other motorists were locked in blankets of snow on a major roadway overnight after nearly 10 inches of snow fell within 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The E22 roadway in Sweden on Thursday. The authorities said that rescue workers had evacuated everyone who wanted to leave their cars by Thursday afternoon.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Daughter Is His Likely Successor, South Korea Says
item.description: Kim Ju-ae has long accompanied her dictator father to important state events, like long-range missile tests and military parades.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Korean Central News Agency on Monday was said to show Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, with his daughter, Kim Ju-ae, in Pyongyang.

item.title: A Trophy in Ruins: Evidence Grows That Russia Controls Marinka
item.description: Ukraine said it was defending territory behind the eastern frontline town. Its capture would be Russia’s most significant territorial advance in Ukraine in more than six months.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier along the front line near Marinka in August.

item.title: Vatican Defends Gay Blessings, but Offers Critics Some Leeway
item.description: The clarification on a declaration issued in December seemed designed to soothe critics while also showing that this is the way forward.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Francis leads the Angelus prayer on the World Day of the Poor in St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican in November.

item.title: Canada’s Boreal Forests Badly Damaged by Logging
item.description: A study finds that logging has inflicted severe damage to the vast boreal forests in Ontario and Quebec, two of the country’s main commercial logging regions.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portion of boreal forest in northern Quebec. A study found that commercial logging in Quebec and neighboring Ontario has caused the removal of 35.4 million acres of forest.

item.title: Islamic State Takes Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Iran
item.description: The group, which has struck before in Iran, has a long history of division with the country.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Hwaida Saad and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli/ISNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Iran’s state-run news media on Wednesday of the site of the explosions in the city of Kerman.

item.title: Experts See a Message in Chinese Balloons Flying Over Taiwan
item.description: Some analysts see the objects as a calculatedly ambiguous reminder to voters that Beijing is watching.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Folding a flag of Taiwan in the island’s capital, Taipei. The balloons from China do not appear to pose an immediate military menace.

item.title: Who Was the Iranian General Qassim Suleimani?
item.description: General Suleimani, the powerful commander heading Iran’s Quds Force, was considered a hero by some in the country. The anniversary of his death has attracted horrific violence.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gathering of mourners in Tehran after the death of Qassim Suleimani in 2020.

item.title: Menendez Case Focuses on How Qatar Trades Its Riches for Clout
item.description: The tiny Gulf state has cultivated relationships with powerful people and institutions to raise its global profile, and to protect its interests.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, is accused of using his position to benefit Egypt and Qatar.

item.title: Mexico Officials Rescue 31 Migrants Abducted Near U.S. Border
item.description: Cartels are preying on asylum seekers and migrants from around the world as they crowd northern Mexico, creating a kidnap-for-ransom revenue stream.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: David, a migrant from South America, in Matamoros, Mexico, last May after several days of being beaten and held hostage by a cartel that kidnaps migrants in northern Mexico.

item.title: Indonesia Train Crash Kills at Least 3, Official Says
item.description: A local police chief said three crew members had died in the collision, which took place near the city of Bandung, southeast of Jakarta on the island of Java.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono

item.title: Lebanese and Israelis Flee Homes Along Border Amid Fighting
item.description: More than 150,000 people have been driven from their homes on both sides of the frontier as Israeli forces clash with Hezbollah militants.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Roni Rabin, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery unit firing toward a target in Lebanon from Israel on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Islamic State Claims the Iran Bombing
item.description: Plus the seven keys to longevity.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli/ISNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Iran’s state-run news media on Wednesday of the site of the explosions in the city of Kerman.

item.title: Education Dept. Official Resigns Over Biden’s Policies on Israel and Gaza
item.description: Tariq Habash, who is Palestinian American, said the Biden administration “does not value all human life equally.”
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies of Palestinians killed at Nasser Hospital, in the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis, in December.

item.title: White House Says North Korea Providing Russia With Ballistic Missiles
item.description: Russia has rebuilt its own domestic supply of cruise missiles, but to keep up with the intensity of the barrage against Ukraine, it has been turning to North Korea and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Kirby, a White House spokesman, said that a series of North Korean-produced missiles were fired into Ukraine from Russia.

item.title: Mike Sadler, Intrepid Desert Navigator in World War II, Dies at 103
item.description: Like a human GPS, he guided Britain’s first special forces across the vast Sahara for hit-and-run raids on enemy bases in the battle against Rommel’s forces.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden

item.title: Why London’s Tube Is Shutting Down Next Week
item.description: Large strikes by workers on the London Underground are expected to cripple the capital’s transportation network for several days.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Efren Landaos/Sipa USA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The London Underground system will be largely shut down for most of next week.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A deadly blast in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mahdi Karbakhsh Ravari/Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press

item.title: Princess Mary of Denmark, Australia’s Homegrown Heroine
item.description: “I don’t recall wishing that one day I would be a princess,” Princess Mary told reporters. “I wanted to be a veterinarian.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mary in 2023. She is admired in both her native Australia and her adopted country of Denmark for combining elegance of dress with a down-to-earth manner and embrace of progressive causes.

item.title: Israelis Fear Assassination of Hamas Deputy May Disrupt Hostage Talks
item.description: Israelis welcomed news that a top Palestinian militant had been killed, but feared that it might impede the release of hostages and kindle a broader war.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A top Hamas official, Saleh al-Arouri, was killed in an explosion outside Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Attacks Heighten Fears of a Wider War for the Middle East and U.S.
item.description: The killing of a top Hamas leader in Lebanon and mysterious twin explosions in Iran heighten fears of a regional war that could draw in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Sare Tajalli, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing emergency personnel near the blast site in Kerman, Iran.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Pledges Revenge for Killing of a Hamas Leader in Beirut
item.description: “Yesterday’s crime will not go unpunished,” Hassan Nasrallah warned ominously, but he gave no specifics, saying he would speak again on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, greeting supporters via video link during a highly anticipated speech on Wednesday. He said he would speak again on Friday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Blasts in Iran Kill Dozens
item.description: Plus, China shakes up its military.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showed emergency personnel at the blast site in Kerman, Iran.

item.title: Israel Supreme Court Delivers Setback to Campaign to Remove Checks on Netanyahu
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court ruled to postpone the adoption of a new law making it harder to designate a sitting prime minister unfit for office, a direct blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv, in December.

item.title: Israel Says It Dismantled a Hamas Tunnel Under Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: The Israeli military says the tearing down was done in November and that hospital wasn’t damaged in the process.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier in November near a stone-and-concrete shaft on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital, a sprawling complex in Gaza City.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Record Number of P.O.W.s
item.description: The exchange of prisoners was the first in months and came as both sides were engaged in an escalating cycle of air assaults.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service showing Ukrainian prisoners of war after a swap at an unknown location in Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Swedish Teenager Was on Japan Airlines Flight 516. Here’s His Story.
item.description: Anton Deibe, 17, and his family were flying into Tokyo when their plane collided with a Coast Guard aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson

item.title: First Case of Lethal Bird Flu in Polar Bears Reported in Alaska
item.description: Tissue samples from a polar bear that was found dead have tested positive for the virus.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: A polar bear in Kaktovik, Alaska in 2016.

item.title: Leader’s Killing Is a Blow, but Not a Knockout, for Hamas
item.description: The killing of Saleh al-Arouri, a key Hamas strategist, in Lebanon sets the organization back at a vulnerable time. The group has rebuilt after the assassination of other leaders, though.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Workers cleaning the street near the site of an explosion that killed Saleh al-Arouri, a senior Hamas leader, in Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: Over 100 Killed in Iran Blasts at Qassim Suleimani Memorial
item.description: No one claimed responsibility for the bombing at a memorial for Qassim Suleimani, the top commander killed by a U.S. drone strike four years ago.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing emergency personnel at the blast site in Kerman, Iran. The explosions struck the road toward the cemetery, officials said.

item.title: Order and Calm Eased Evacuation from Burning Japan Airlines Jet
item.description: In addition to a well-trained crew and an advanced plane, the safe evacuation of 367 passengers came down to a relative absence of panic.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A Japan Airlines plane that burned after a collision with a Japan Coast Guard aircraft at Haneda Airport in Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Al-Arouri’s killing is a blow to Hamas, though likely not a debilitating one, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: People search for survivors following a strike in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Attack on Opposition Leader Raises Alarms in Divided South Korea
item.description: The attack on Lee Jae-myung, who narrowly lost the 2022 presidential vote, came amid a deepening political divide and increasingly extreme discourse in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and John Yoon

item.title: ‘World’s Oldest Pyramid’? A Study’s Claim Troubles Archaeologists
item.description: The study, under investigation by its publisher, has fueled a dispute over the age of a partially excavated site and prompted warnings about the dangers of nationalist mythmaking.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Rin Hindryati and Ulet Ifansasti
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The Gunung Padang site in Cianjur, Indonesia, in December.

item.title: ‘It’s State Propaganda’: Ukrainians Shun TV News as War Drags on
item.description: A government-approved news program intended to counter Russian disinformation and boost morale is coming under criticism for painting a rosy picture of the war.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksiy Dmytrashkivskiy, head of public relations for the Ukrainian army, is interviewed by Telemarathon host Vadym Karpiak. Viewership for the show has shrunk as the war has dragged on.

item.title: Junior Doctors at N.H.S. Begin 6-Day Strike
item.description: The young doctors’ walkout could result in numerous canceled medical visits and surgical procedures, undoing recent progress in cutting wait times.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A picket line outside St. Thomas’ Hospital in central London on Wednesday.

item.title: Hamas blames Israel for the death of a senior official in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People search for survivors following a strike in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Dismissals Point to Xi Jinping’s Quiet Shake-Up of China’s Military
item.description: The purge of several commanders from China’s legislature was the latest sign of widening investigations focused on the sensitive arms sector, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader Xi Jinping at a military parade in 2019. Experts say he appears to be rooting out corruption in agencies responsible for developing weapons and military installations.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The killing of a Hamas leader.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People search for survivors following a strike in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Hamas Used Gaza Hospital as a Command Center, U.S. Intelligence Says
item.description: Israeli forces stormed the site in November, drawing intense international scrutiny and criticism.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The Al-Shifa Hospital complex was used by both Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad forces fighting against Israel, according to new U.S. intelligence.

item.title: Netanyahu Allies Signal No Immediate Countermoves to Supreme Court Ruling
item.description: With Israel fighting in Gaza, people on both sides of the judiciary debate appear unwilling to return to the domestic upheaval that preceded the war.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Roni Rabin
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and Justice Minister Yariv Levin in the Knesset, in March.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Beirut Blast Kills Senior Hamas Leader
item.description: Plus the great winter festivals of Asia.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People working inside an apartment following a massive explosion in the southern suburb of Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Maureen Flavin Sweeney Dies at 100; Her Weather Report Delayed D-Day
item.description: She helped save General Eisenhower’s invasion from potential disaster, enabling the Allies to gain a foothold in France that was essential to victory in World War II.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Who Was Saleh al-Arouri, the Senior Hamas Leader Killed in Beirut?
item.description: The Hamas deputy, who the group said had been killed, helped usher in closer ties with the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia and was accused of masterminding attacks in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Saleh al-Arouri in Cairo in 2017.

item.title: Deputy Hamas Leader Is Killed in Lebanon as Fears Grow of a Wider War
item.description: The Israeli government would not comment on the death of Saleh al-Arouri. But a U.S. official said to expect Israel to assassinate Hamas officials “for years.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Euan Ward and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: People search for survivors following a strike in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Spanish Soccer Star Testifies About Unwanted Kiss
item.description: Jennifer Hermoso, who was kissed on the mouth by Spain’s former soccer boss, Luis Rubiales, gave evidence at a hearing to determine whether Mr. Rubiales will be charged.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Jennifer Hermoso, center, leaving on Tuesday after a hearing at the National Court in Madrid.

item.title: Somaliland Deal to Grant Ethiopia Red Sea Access Draws Condemnation
item.description: A landmark pact between Ethiopia and the breakaway region of Somaliland has drawn condemnation from Somalia. Other neighbors also worry about allowing potential naval access to the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The Somaliland port of Berbera in 2018. A preliminary deal has been struck to give Ethiopia commercial and military access to the territory’s port in the Gulf of Aden.

item.title: Denmark’s Prince Frederik Represents a New Generation of Monarchs
item.description: Like King Charles III of Britain, Prince Frederik, who will soon ascend to his country’s throne, is part of a younger generation of royals who have embraced environmental issues.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Prince Frederik of Denmark, with his mother, Queen Margrethe, at the opening of the Danish Parliament in October.

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Adds to Questions Over Kind of State Israel Will Be
item.description: Monday’s court ruling joined the war in Gaza in a widening crisis over what kind of state Israel will be.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The Israeli Supreme Court in September last year. Its decision on Monday displayed anew the cultural war at the heart of the country’s politics.

item.title: Jimmy Lai Pleads Not Guilty to Hong Kong Security Law Charges
item.description: The prosecution accused him of colluding with U.S. officials to undermine Hong Kong’s interests, citing private messages, meetings and social media posts.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai at Apple Daily, the newspaper he founded, in 2020.

item.title: Indiana’s Plan to Pipe In Groundwater for Microchip-Making Draws Fire
item.description: The state is courting high-tech investments, but a new industrial park may lack enough water. Opponents say piping it from miles away might dry out residential wells.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a major industrial park near Lebanon, Ind., in July.

item.title: 5 Killed After Japan Airlines Plane Collision at Tokyo Airport
item.description: Japan Airlines said all 367 passengers and 12 crew members had safely evacuated the jet. But five crew members on a Japanese Coast Guard plane that collided with it were killed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Hisako Ueno, Kaly Soto and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A Japan Airlines plane in flames at Haneda Airport in Tokyo on Tuesday.
